channel.title: VS Code on Sujith Quintelier
channel.description: Recent content in VS Code on Sujith Quintelier

item.title: azure: [Launched] Generally Available: Azure SQL updates for late-February 2026
item.description:
Late-February 2026 Azure SQL updates add a database object search feature to the MSSQL extension for Visual Studio Code.

  • Source: Azure Updates

item.title: azure: [In preview] Public Preview: Azure SQL updates for mid-February 2026
item.description:
Mid-February 2026 Azure SQL preview adds new Visual Studio Code publishing support for SQL Projects and introduces a Connections Migration dialog to import existing workflows.

  • Source: Azure Updates

item.title: vscode: Giving Agents a Visual Voice: MCP Apps Support in VS Code
item.description:
Visual Studio Code adds support for MCP Apps so AI agents can present interactive user interfaces inside the editor, enabling richer and more integrated developer workflows.

  • Source: Visual Studio Code

item.title: vscode: Building docfind: Fast Client-Side Search with Rust and WebAssembly
item.description:
The article describes building docfind, a high-performance client-side search engine implemented in Rust and compiled to WebAssembly, and highlights how GitHub Copilot sped up development.

  • Source: Visual Studio Code

item.title: vscode: Introducing the VS Code Insiders Podcast
item.description:
Announcement of the VS Code Insiders Podcast â€” a new series serving as an insider’s guide to the features, decisions, and people shaping the future of Visual Studio Code.

  • Source: Visual Studio Code

item.title: azure: [Launched] Generally Available: Private Marketplace for VS Code
item.description:
The VS Code Private Marketplace is now generally available. It provides a secure, enterprise-ready solution to host and manage VS Code extensions internally, fully integrated with VS Code and designed for teams that need control over deployment and updates.

  • Source: Azure Updates

item.title: vscode: Expanding Model Choice in VS Code with Bring Your Own Key
item.description:
The VS Code blog post introduces the new Language Model Chat Provider API and a Bring Your Own Key (BYOK) experience that lets extensions and users choose and integrate different language models for chat functionality, increasing model choice and extensibility in the editor.

  • Source: Visual Studio Code

item.title: vscode: Introducing auto model selection (preview)
item.description:
VS Code now offers auto model selection (preview) to automatically choose the best AI model for faster responses, reduced rate limiting, and a 10% discount on premium requests for paid users.

  • Source: Visual Studio Code
